/app/src/ast.rs:
    1|       |//! Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) for C11 compiler.
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides the core AST data structures and APIs for representing
    4|       |//! C11 programs. The AST is designed as a flattened storage system for efficiency,
    5|       |//! with index-based references to child nodes and types.
    6|       |//!
    7|       |//! ## Architecture
    8|       |//!
    9|       |//! The AST is organized into focused submodules for better maintainability:
   10|       |//!
   11|       |//! - [`nodes`]: Node definitions, constructors, and builder patterns for AST nodes
   12|       |//! - [`types`]: Type system representation and utilities for semantic analysis
   13|       |//!
   14|       |//! ## Key Features
   15|       |//!
   16|       |//! - **Flattened Storage**: All AST nodes are stored in contiguous vectors with index-based references
   17|       |//! - **Interior Mutability**: Uses `Cell` for type annotations without requiring mutable AST access
   18|       |//! - **Builder Patterns**: Ergonomic constructors for complex AST nodes
   19|       |//! - **Type System**: Canonical types distinct from syntactic type specifiers
   20|       |//!
   21|       |
   22|       |use std::num::NonZeroU32;
   23|       |
   24|       |/// Represents an interned string using symbol_table crate.
   25|       |/// Alias for GlobalSymbol from symbol_table crate with global feature.
   26|       |pub type NameId = symbol_table::GlobalSymbol;
   27|       |

  154|  2.70k|            None

  293|       |    /// Get function name from symbol entry reference
  294|      4|    fn get_function_name(symbol_ref: SymbolRef, symbol_table: Option<&SymbolTable>) -> String {
  295|      4|        if let Some(table) = symbol_table {
  296|      4|            let entry = table.get_symbol(symbol_ref);

  298|      0|        }
  299|      0|        format!("func_{}", symbol_ref.get())
  300|      4|    }

  302|       |    /// Format a DesignatedInitializer for display
  303|      4|    fn format_designated_initializer(init: &DesignatedInitializer, ast: &Ast) -> String {
  304|      4|        let mut result = String::new();
  305|      4|        for designator_ref in init.designator_start.range(init.designator_len) {
  306|      4|            match ast.get_kind(designator_ref) {
  307|      4|                NodeKind::Designator(d) => match d {
  308|      2|                    Designator::FieldName(name) => {
  309|      2|                        result.push_str(&format!(".{}", name));
  310|      2|                    }
  311|      2|                    Designator::ArrayIndex(index) => {
  312|      2|                        result.push_str(&format!("[{}]", index.get()));
  313|      2|                    }
  314|      0|                    Designator::GnuArrayRange(start, end) => {
  315|      0|                        result.push_str(&format!("[{} ... {}]", start.get(), end.get()));
  316|      0|                    }
  317|       |                },
  318|      0|                _ => result.push_str("<invalid designator>"),
  319|       |            }
  320|       |        }
  321|       |
  322|      4|        if init.designator_len > 0 {
  323|      4|            result.push_str(" = ");
  324|      4|        }
                      ^0
  325|       |
  326|      4|        result.push_str(&init.initializer.get().to_string());
  327|      4|        result
  328|      4|    }

    7|       |    // string slices and `eq_ignore_ascii_case` calls. By working with bytes directly
    8|       |    // and using `matches!` for character comparisons, we avoid the overhead of
    9|       |    // slicing and function calls in the common cases, resulting in a small but
   10|       |    // measurable performance improvement for parsing integer literals.

   12|    927|    let len = bytes.len();
   13|       |
   14|    927|    if len == 0 {
   15|      0|        return (text, None);
   16|    927|    }

   19|    927|    if len >= 3 {

   26|       |    /// Dump preprocessed output to stdout
   27|      3|    pub(crate) fn dump_preprocessed_output(
   28|      3|        &self,
   29|      3|        pp_tokens: &[PPToken],
   30|      3|        suppress_line_markers: bool,
   31|      3|        source_manager: &SourceManager,
   32|      3|    ) -> Result<(), DriverError> {
   33|      3|        if pp_tokens.is_empty() {
   34|      0|            return Ok(());
   35|      3|        }
   36|       |
   37|       |        // Get the source buffer for the first token
   38|      3|        let first_token = &pp_tokens[0];
   39|       |
   40|       |        // Initial heuristic: try to find the first non-macro-expanded token
   41|       |        // to establish the "current file" context. This prevents line markers
   42|       |        // generally being emitted for the file itself if it starts with a macro.
   43|      3|        let mut current_file_id = first_token.location.source_id();
   44|      3|        for token in pp_tokens {
   45|      3|            if !token.flags.contains(crate::pp::PPTokenFlags::MACRO_EXPANDED) {
   46|      3|                current_file_id = token.location.source_id();
   47|      3|                break;
   48|      0|            }
   49|       |        }
   50|      3|        let mut current_buffer = source_manager.get_buffer(current_file_id);
   51|      3|        let mut last_pos = 0u32;
   52|      3|        let mut last_was_macro_expanded = false;
   53|       |
   54|     22|        for token in pp_tokens {
                          ^19
   55|     19|            if token.kind == crate::pp::PPTokenKind::Eof {
   56|      0|                break;
   57|     19|            }
   58|       |
   59|       |            // Handle macro-expanded tokens (Level A: use canonical spelling)
   60|     19|            if token.flags.contains(crate::pp::PPTokenFlags::MACRO_EXPANDED) {
   61|       |                // Heuristic: if we are entering a macro expansion (previous was not macro),
   62|       |                // and there was whitespace at the current position in the source, print a space.
   63|       |                // This preserves separation like "return FOO" -> "return 123".
   64|      2|                if !last_was_macro_expanded {
   65|       |                    // Check if char at last_pos is whitespace
   66|      2|                    if let Some(&byte) = current_buffer.get(last_pos as usize)
   67|      2|                        && (byte as char).is_whitespace()
   68|      2|                    {
   69|      2|                        print!(" ");
   70|      2|                    }
                                  ^0
   71|      0|                } else {
   72|      0|                    // Add space between consecutive macro-expanded tokens (linearization)
   73|      0|                    print!(" ");
   74|      0|                }
   75|       |
   76|       |                // For macro-expanded tokens, just print the canonical spelling
   77|       |                // No whitespace reconstruction for Level A - these tokens don't have
   78|       |                // meaningful source locations for whitespace calculation
   79|      2|                print!("{}", token.get_text());
   80|      2|                last_was_macro_expanded = true;
   81|       |                // Don't update last_pos for macro-expanded tokens
   82|      2|                continue;

  461|       |    /// Get all tokens from the stream
  462|    515|    pub fn tokenize_all(&mut self) -> Vec<Token> {
  463|       |        // Bolt : Pre-allocate the tokens vector with the capacity of the preprocessor tokens.
  464|       |        // This is a reasonable estimate that reduces the number of reallocations,
  465|       |        // as the number of lexical tokens is usually similar to the number of preprocessor tokens.
  466|    515|        let mut tokens = Vec::with_capacity(self.tokens.len());
  467|    515|        let mut current_token_iter = self.tokens.iter().peekable();
  468|       |
  469|  10.9k|        while let Some(pptoken) = current_token_iter.next() {
  470|  10.9k|            if let PPTokenKind::StringLiteral(symbol) = pptoken.kind {
                                                            ^86
  471|       |                //  Bolt: Optimized string literal handling.
  472|       |                // This introduces a fast path for single string literals, which are the
  473|       |                // most common case. By peeking ahead, we avoid the overhead of the
  474|       |                // two-pass concatenation logic unless it's actually needed. This
  475|       |                // reduces overhead and improves lexer performance.
  476|       |
  477|       |                // --- Fast path for single string literals ---
  478|     80|                if !matches!(
  479|     86|                    current_token_iter.peek(),
  480|       |                    Some(PPToken {
  481|       |                        kind: PPTokenKind::StringLiteral(_),
  482|       |                        ..
  483|       |                    })
  484|       |                ) {
  485|     80|                    tokens.push(Token {
  486|     80|                        kind: self.classify_token(pptoken), // Handles quote stripping
  487|     80|                        span: SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  488|     80|                            pptoken.location.source_id(),
  489|     80|                            pptoken.location.offset(),
  490|     80|                            pptoken.length as u32,
  491|     80|                        ),
  492|     80|                    });
  493|     80|                    continue;
  494|      6|                }
  495|       |
  496|       |                // --- Slow path: Concatenate adjacent string literals ---
  497|      6|                let start_span = SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  498|      6|                    pptoken.location.source_id(),
  499|      6|                    pptoken.location.offset(),
  500|      6|                    pptoken.length as u32,
  501|       |                );
  502|      6|                let mut final_span = start_span;
  503|       |
  504|       |                // --- Phase 1: Calculate total size and find last span ---
  505|      6|                let mut total_size = Self::extract_string_content(&symbol).unwrap_or("").len();
  506|      6|                let mut adjacent_literals = 0;
  507|      6|                let next_token_idx = self.tokens.len() - current_token_iter.len();
  508|       |
  509|     15|                while let Some(next_pptoken) = self.tokens.get(next_token_idx + adjacent_literals) {
  510|     15|                    if let PPTokenKind::StringLiteral(next_symbol) = next_pptoken.kind {
                                                                    ^9
  511|      9|                        total_size += Self::extract_string_content(&next_symbol).unwrap_or("").len();
  512|      9|                        final_span = SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  513|      9|                            next_pptoken.location.source_id(),
  514|      9|                            next_pptoken.location.offset(),
  515|      9|                            next_pptoken.length as u32,
  516|      9|                        );
  517|      9|                        adjacent_literals += 1;
  518|      9|                    } else {
  519|      6|                        break;
  520|       |                    }
  521|       |                }
  522|       |
  523|       |                // --- Phase 2: Allocate and append ---
  524|      6|                let mut content = String::with_capacity(total_size);
  525|      6|                if let Some(s_content) = Self::extract_string_content(&symbol) {
  526|      6|                    literal_parsing::unescape_string_into(s_content, &mut content);
  527|      6|                }
                              ^0
  528|       |
  529|      6|                for _ in 0..adjacent_literals {
  530|      9|                    let consumed_pptoken = current_token_iter.next().unwrap();
  531|      9|                    if let PPTokenKind::StringLiteral(next_symbol) = consumed_pptoken.kind
  532|      9|                        && let Some(s_content) = Self::extract_string_content(&next_symbol)
  533|      9|                    {
  534|      9|                        literal_parsing::unescape_string_into(s_content, &mut content);
  535|      9|                    }
                                  ^0
  536|       |                }
  537|       |
  538|      6|                tokens.push(Token {
  539|      6|                    kind: TokenKind::StringLiteral(StringId::new(content)),
  540|      6|                    span: start_span.merge(final_span),
  541|      6|                });
  542|      6|                continue;
  543|  10.8k|            }
  544|       |
  545|       |            // For all other tokens, process normally
  546|  10.8k|            let token = Token {
  547|  10.8k|                kind: self.classify_token(pptoken),
  548|  10.8k|                span: SourceSpan::new_with_length(
  549|  10.8k|                    pptoken.location.source_id(),
  550|  10.8k|                    pptoken.location.offset(),
  551|  10.8k|                    pptoken.length as u32,
  552|  10.8k|                ),
  553|  10.8k|            };

                                       ^10.3k

  557|  10.8k|            if is_eof {
  558|    515|                break;
  559|  10.3k|            }
  560|       |        }

    1|       |//! Mid-level Intermediate Representation (MIR) for C11 compiler.
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides the MIR data structures and APIs for representing
    4|       |//! C11 programs after semantic analysis. The MIR is designed to be:
    5|       |//! - Typed: All entities have explicit types
    6|       |//! - Explicit: All C semantics are made explicit
    7|       |//! - Cranelift-friendly: Easy to lower to Cranelift IR
    8|       |//! - Non-SSA: Uses basic blocks with explicit control flow
    9|       |

/app/src/mir/codegen.rs:
    1|       |//! MIR to Cranelift IR lowering module
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides the mechanical translation from MIR to Cranelift IR.
    4|       |//! The translation follows these rules:
    5|       |//! - No C logic
    6|       |//! - Assume MIR is valid
    7|       |
    8|       |use crate::mir::MirProgram;
    9|       |use crate::mir::{
   10|       |    BinaryFloatOp, BinaryIntOp, CallTarget, ConstValueId, ConstValueKind, GlobalId, LocalId, MirBlockId, MirFunction,
   11|       |    MirFunctionId, MirFunctionKind, MirStmt, MirType, Operand, Place, Rvalue, Terminator, TypeId, UnaryFloatOp,
   12|       |    UnaryIntOp,
   13|       |};

   15|       |use cranelift::prelude::{
   16|       |    AbiParam, Block, Configurable, FloatCC, FunctionBuilderContext, InstBuilder, IntCC, MemFlags, Signature, Type,
   17|       |    Value, types,
   18|       |};

   38|       |/// Helper function to convert MIR type to Cranelift type
   39|       |/// Returns None for void types, as they don't have a representation in Cranelift
   40|    711|fn convert_type(mir_type: &MirType) -> Option<Type> {
   41|    711|    match mir_type {
   42|     25|        MirType::Void => None,
   43|      4|        MirType::Bool => Some(types::I8), // Booleans as i8 (standard C)
   44|       |
   45|     20|        MirType::I8 | MirType::U8 => Some(types::I8),
   46|     10|        MirType::I16 | MirType::U16 => Some(types::I16),
   47|    416|        MirType::I32 | MirType::U32 => Some(types::I32),
   48|     51|        MirType::I64 | MirType::U64 => Some(types::I64),
   49|      0|        MirType::F32 => Some(types::F32),
   50|     10|        MirType::F64 => Some(types::F64),
   51|      5|        MirType::F80 | MirType::F128 => Some(types::F128),
   52|    147|        MirType::Pointer { .. } => Some(types::I64), // Pointers are 64-bit on most modern systems
   53|       |
   54|     22|        MirType::Array { .. } | MirType::Record { .. } => None,
   55|      1|        MirType::Function { .. } => Some(types::I64), // Function pointers
   56|       |    }
   57|    711|}

   61|    156|    match kind {
   62|     65|        MirFunctionKind::Extern => Linkage::Import,
   63|     91|        MirFunctionKind::Defined => Linkage::Export,
   64|       |    }

   67|       |/// Helper function to get the size of a MIR type in bytes
   68|    250|pub(crate) fn mir_type_size(mir_type: &MirType, mir: &MirProgram) -> Result<u32, String> {
   69|    250|    match mir_type {
   70|    132|        MirType::I8 | MirType::U8 => Ok(1),
   71|      2|        MirType::I16 | MirType::U16 => Ok(2),
   72|     74|        MirType::I32 | MirType::U32 => Ok(4),
   73|      3|        MirType::I64 | MirType::U64 => Ok(8),
   74|      0|        MirType::F32 => Ok(4),
   75|      1|        MirType::F64 => Ok(8),
   76|      5|        MirType::F80 | MirType::F128 => Ok(16),
   77|       |
   78|     10|        MirType::Pointer { .. } => Ok(mir.pointer_width as u32),
   79|      7|        MirType::Array { layout, .. } => Ok(layout.size as u32),

  146|      0|fn f64_to_f128_bytes(val: f64) -> [u8; 16] {
  147|      0|    let bits = val.to_bits();
  148|      0|    let sign = (bits >> 63) & 1;
  149|      0|    let exp = (bits >> 52) & 0x7FF;
  150|      0|    let mant = bits & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFF;
  151|       |
  152|      0|    let (new_exp, new_mant) = if exp == 0 {
  153|      0|        if mant == 0 {
  154|       |            // Zero
  155|      0|            (0, 0)
  156|       |        } else {
  157|       |            // Subnormal f64 -> Normal f128
  158|       |            // mant is 0.bbbb... (52 bits)
  159|      0|            let lz = mant.leading_zeros() - (64 - 52);
  160|      0|            let shift = lz + 1;
  161|      0|            let normalized_mant = mant << shift;
  162|      0|            let payload = normalized_mant & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFF; // 52 bits
  163|       |
  164|      0|            let unbiased_exp = -1022 - (shift as i32);
  165|      0|            let biased_exp = unbiased_exp + 16383;
  166|       |
  167|      0|            (biased_exp as u64, (payload as u128) << (112 - 52))
  168|       |        }
  169|      0|    } else if exp == 0x7FF {
  170|       |        // Inf or NaN
  171|      0|        (0x7FFF, (mant as u128) << (112 - 52))
  172|       |    } else {
  173|       |        // Normal
  174|      0|        let unbiased_exp = (exp as i32) - 1023;
  175|      0|        let biased_exp = unbiased_exp + 16383;
  176|      0|        (biased_exp as u64, (mant as u128) << (112 - 52))
  177|       |    };
  178|       |
  179|      0|    let sign_bit = (sign as u128) << 127;
  180|      0|    let exp_bits = (new_exp as u128) << 112;
  181|      0|    let mant_bits = new_mant;
  182|       |
  183|      0|    let result = sign_bit | exp_bits | mant_bits;
  184|      0|    result.to_le_bytes()
  185|      0|}
  186|       |
  187|      1|fn f64_to_x87_bytes(val: f64) -> [u8; 16] {
  188|      1|    let bits = val.to_bits();
  189|      1|    let sign = (bits >> 63) & 1;
  190|      1|    let exp = (bits >> 52) & 0x7FF;
  191|      1|    let mant = bits & 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFF;
  192|       |
  193|      1|    let mut out = [0u8; 16];
  194|       |
  195|      1|    if exp == 0 {
  196|      0|        if mant == 0 {
  197|       |            // Zero
  198|      0|            if sign == 1 {
  199|      0|                out[9] = 0x80;
  200|      0|            }
  201|      0|            return out;
  202|      0|        }
  203|       |
  204|       |        // Subnormal f64
  205|       |        // Calculate leading zeros in the 52-bit mantissa
  206|       |        // 12 zeros because u64 has 64 bits but mant only 52
  207|      0|        let lz = mant.leading_zeros() - 12;
  208|       |
  209|       |        // Shift to make MSB 1 (integer bit for x87)
  210|       |        // We want to put the first '1' at bit 63.
  211|       |        // Currently it is at (51 - lz).
  212|       |        // Shift left by 63 - (51 - lz) = 12 + lz.
  213|      0|        let new_mant = mant << (12 + lz);
  214|       |
  215|       |        // Exponent calculation
  216|       |        // Real exponent of f64 subnormal is -1022.
  217|       |        // We effectively shifted left by (lz + 1) to normalize (because we moved 0.1... to 1.0...)
  218|       |        // So we must subtract (lz + 1) from exponent.
  219|      0|        let real_exp = -1022 - (lz as i32 + 1);
  220|       |
  221|       |        // x87 bias 16383
  222|      0|        let new_exp_biased = (real_exp + 16383) as u16;
  223|       |
  224|      0|        out[0..8].copy_from_slice(&new_mant.to_le_bytes());
  225|      0|        out[8..10].copy_from_slice(&new_exp_biased.to_le_bytes());
  226|      0|        if sign == 1 {
  227|      0|            out[9] |= 0x80;
  228|      0|        }
  229|      0|        return out;
  230|      1|    } else if exp == 0x7FF {
  231|       |        // Inf or NaN
  232|      0|        out[8] = 0xFF;
  233|      0|        out[9] = 0x7F | ((sign as u8) << 7);
  234|       |
  235|      0|        if mant == 0 {
  236|      0|            // Infinity: Integer bit 1, mantissa 0
  237|      0|            out[7] = 0x80;
  238|      0|        } else {
  239|      0|            // NaN: Set integer bit 1
  240|      0|            // f64 mantissa is 52 bits. x87 is 63 bits.
  241|      0|            // Shift left by 11.
  242|      0|            let new_mant = (1u64 << 63) | (mant << 11);
  243|      0|            out[0..8].copy_from_slice(&new_mant.to_le_bytes());
  244|      0|        }
  245|      0|        return out;
  246|      1|    }
  247|       |
  248|       |    // Normal f64
  249|      1|    let unbiased_exp = (exp as i32) - 1023;
  250|      1|    let new_exp = (unbiased_exp + 16383) as u16;
  251|       |
  252|       |    // Explicit integer bit 1 for Normal numbers in x87
  253|      1|    let new_mant = (1u64 << 63) | (mant << 11);
  254|       |
  255|      1|    out[0..8].copy_from_slice(&new_mant.to_le_bytes());
  256|      1|    out[8..10].copy_from_slice(&new_exp.to_le_bytes());
  257|       |
  258|       |    // Sign bit in byte 9, bit 7
  259|      1|    if sign == 1 {
  260|      0|        out[9] |= 0x80;
  261|      1|    }
  262|       |
  263|      1|    out
  264|      1|}

  294|      1|fn emit_const_struct(
  295|      1|    fields: &[(usize, ConstValueId)],
  296|      1|    ty: &MirType,
  297|      1|    output: &mut Vec<u8>,
  298|      1|    ctx: &EmitContext,
  299|      1|    mut module: Option<&mut ObjectModule>,
  300|      1|    mut data_description: Option<&mut DataDescription>,

  306|       |            field_types: _,

  309|       |            // Initialize the entire struct with zeros
  310|      1|            let struct_size = record_layout.size as usize;
  311|      1|            let mut struct_bytes = vec![0u8; struct_size];
  312|       |

  323|      2|                        reborrow_module(&mut module),
  324|      2|                        reborrow_data_description(&mut data_description),
  325|      2|                        base_offset + field_offset as u32,
  326|      0|                    )?;
  327|       |
  328|       |                    // Copy the field bytes into the struct buffer
  329|      2|                    let required_size = field_offset + field_bytes.len();
  330|      2|                    if required_size > struct_bytes.len() {
  331|      0|                        struct_bytes.resize(required_size, 0);
  332|      2|                    }

  334|      0|                }

  336|      1|            output.extend_from_slice(&struct_bytes);
  337|      1|            Ok(())

  339|      0|        _ => Err("StructLiteral with non-record type".to_string()),

  587|       |/// Helper to resolve arguments for a call, handling variadic struct expansion if needed
  588|     12|fn resolve_call_args(
  589|     12|    args: &[Operand],
  590|     12|    fixed_param_count: usize,
  591|     12|    sig: &Signature,
  592|     12|    ctx: &mut BodyEmitContext,
  593|     12|    is_variadic: bool,

  601|      0|            break;

  642|      1|                let num_slots = size.div_ceil(8) as usize;

  654|      0|                            ctx.builder.ins().load(types::I64, MemFlags::new(), struct_addr, offset)

  666|      1|                                current_val = ctx.builder.ins().bor(current_val, shifted);
  667|      1|                            }

  928|       |        } else {

  930|       |        };
  931|     25|    }
  932|       |
  933|       |    // Float to Integer
  934|     25|    if from.is_float() && to.is_int() {

  938|       |            // Convert to I32 first, then reduce

  945|      0|        }
  946|       |
  947|      0|        return if is_signed {
  948|      0|            builder.ins().fcvt_to_sint(to, val)
  949|       |        } else {
  950|      0|            builder.ins().fcvt_to_uint(to, val)
  951|       |        };
  952|     23|    }
  953|       |
  954|       |    // General Integer/Pointer/Bool conversions (Extension/Reduction/Bitcast)
  955|     23|    let from_width = from.bits();

  964|       |        }
  965|      7|    } else if from_width > to_width {
  966|       |        // Reduction

  968|       |    } else {
  969|       |        // Same width, diff types (e.g. I64 <-> F64 bitcast, or I32 <-> F32 bitcast, or Pointer types)

  971|       |        // Actually bitcast works for any same-sized types.
  972|      0|        builder.ins().bitcast(to, MemFlags::new(), val)
  973|       |    }

 1125|       |/// Helper function to resolve a MIR place to a Cranelift value
 1126|     98|fn resolve_place(place: &Place, ctx: &mut BodyEmitContext, expected_type: Type) -> Result<Value, String> {
 1127|     98|    match place {
 1128|     81|        Place::Local(local_id) => {
 1129|       |            // A local place is resolved by loading from its stack slot
 1130|     81|            if let Some(stack_slot) = ctx.stack_slots.get(local_id) {
 1131|     81|                Ok(ctx.builder.ins().stack_load(expected_type, *stack_slot, 0))
 1132|       |            } else {
 1133|      0|                Err(format!("Stack slot not found for local {}", local_id.get()))
 1134|       |            }
 1135|       |        }
 1136|      0|        Place::Global(_global_id) => {
 1137|       |            // First, get the memory address of the global.
 1138|      0|            let addr = resolve_place_to_addr(place, ctx)?;
 1139|       |
 1140|       |            // Then, load the value from that address.
 1141|      0|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().load(expected_type, MemFlags::new(), addr, 0))
 1142|       |        }
 1143|      0|        Place::Deref(operand) => {
 1144|       |            // The address is the value of the operand, so we load from that value
 1145|      0|            let addr = resolve_operand(operand, ctx, types::I64)?;
 1146|      0|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().load(expected_type, MemFlags::new(), addr, 0))
 1147|       |        }
 1148|      7|        Place::StructField(base_place, field_index) => {
 1149|       |            // Get the address of the struct field
 1150|      7|            let addr = resolve_place_to_addr(&Place::StructField(base_place.clone(), *field_index), ctx)?;
                                                                                                                      ^0
 1151|      7|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().load(expected_type, MemFlags::new(), addr, 0))
 1152|       |        }
 1153|     10|        Place::ArrayIndex(base_place, index_operand) => {
 1154|       |            // Get the address of the array element
 1155|     10|            let addr = resolve_place_to_addr(&Place::ArrayIndex(base_place.clone(), index_operand.clone()), ctx)?;
                                                                                                                              ^0
 1156|     10|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().load(expected_type, MemFlags::new(), addr, 0))
 1157|       |        }
 1158|       |    }

 1163|    135|    match operand {
 1164|     58|        Operand::Constant(const_id) => {

 1167|       |

                                      ^48

 1174|     10|            match &const_value.kind {
 1175|       |                // Integer literals in MIR are typically used in integer-sized contexts
 1176|       |                // Default to I32 so common small integer constants (like `4`) match i32
 1177|       |                // places instead of being treated as 64-bit immediates.
 1178|      0|                ConstValueKind::Int(_) => Ok(types::I32),
 1179|      0|                ConstValueKind::Float(_) => Ok(types::F64),

 1181|       |                // Null/Zero/Global addresses are pointer-sized
 1182|     10|                ConstValueKind::Null | ConstValueKind::Zero | ConstValueKind::GlobalAddress(_) => Ok(types::I64),
 1183|      0|                ConstValueKind::FunctionAddress(_) => Ok(types::I64),
 1184|      0|                ConstValueKind::StructLiteral(_) => Ok(types::I32),
 1185|      0|                ConstValueKind::ArrayLiteral(_) => Ok(types::I32),
 1186|       |            }
 1187|       |        }
 1188|     44|        Operand::Copy(place) => {
 1189|     44|            let place_type_id = get_place_type_id(place, mir);
 1190|     44|            let place_type = mir.get_type(place_type_id);
 1191|     44|            if place_type.is_aggregate() {
 1192|      0|                return Ok(types::I64);

 1197|     31|            let mir_type = mir.get_type(*type_id);
 1198|     31|            if mir_type.is_aggregate() {
 1199|      0|                return Ok(types::I64);

 1220|       |/// Helper function to get the TypeId of an operand
 1221|     59|fn get_operand_type_id(operand: &Operand, mir: &MirProgram) -> Result<TypeId, String> {
 1222|     59|    match operand {
 1223|     28|        Operand::Constant(const_id) => {

 1241|      0|                }
 1242|       |            }
 1243|      0|            Err("Pointer type not found in MIR types".to_string())
 1244|       |        }
 1245|       |    }

 1260|      0|                _ => panic!("Cannot determine type for deref operand"),

 1291|       |/// Helper function to resolve a MIR place to a memory address
 1292|     68|fn resolve_place_to_addr(place: &Place, ctx: &mut BodyEmitContext) -> Result<Value, String> {
 1293|     68|    match place {
 1294|     30|        Place::Local(local_id) => {
 1295|     30|            if let Some(stack_slot) = ctx.stack_slots.get(local_id) {
 1296|     30|                Ok(ctx.builder.ins().stack_addr(types::I64, *stack_slot, 0))
 1297|       |            } else {
 1298|      0|                Err(format!("Stack slot not found for local {}", local_id.get()))
 1299|       |            }
 1300|       |        }
 1301|      8|        Place::Global(global_id) => {
 1302|      8|            let global = ctx.mir.get_global(*global_id);
 1303|      8|            let linkage = if global.initial_value.is_some() {
 1304|      8|                Linkage::Export
 1305|       |            } else {
 1306|      0|                Linkage::Import
 1307|       |            };
 1308|       |
 1309|      8|            let global_val = ctx
 1310|      8|                .module
 1311|      8|                .declare_data(global.name.as_str(), linkage, true, false)
 1312|      8|                .map_err(|e| format!("Failed to declare global data: {:?}", e))?;
                                           ^0      ^0                                        ^0
 1313|      8|            let local_id = ctx.module.declare_data_in_func(global_val, ctx.builder.func);
 1314|       |            // Use I64 for addresses
 1315|      8|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().global_value(types::I64, local_id))
 1316|       |        }
 1317|      4|        Place::Deref(operand) => {
 1318|       |            // The address is the value of the operand itself (which should be a pointer).
 1319|      4|            resolve_operand(operand, ctx, types::I64)
 1320|       |        }
 1321|     12|        Place::StructField(base_place, field_index) => {
 1322|       |            // Get the base address of the struct
 1323|     12|            let base_addr = resolve_place_to_addr(base_place, ctx)?;
                                                                                ^0
 1324|       |
 1325|       |            // We need to find the type of the base_place to get the pre-computed field offset
 1326|     12|            let base_place_type_id = get_place_type_id(base_place, ctx.mir);
 1327|     12|            let base_type = ctx.mir.get_type(base_place_type_id);
 1328|       |
 1329|     12|            let (field_offset, is_pointer) = match base_type {
 1330|     12|                MirType::Record { layout, .. } => {
 1331|     12|                    let offset = layout
 1332|     12|                        .field_offsets
 1333|     12|                        .get(*field_index)
 1334|     12|                        .copied()
 1335|     12|                        .ok_or_else(|| format!("Field index {} out of bounds", field_index))?;
                                                     ^0      ^0                                           ^0
 1336|     12|                    (offset, false)
 1337|       |                }
 1338|      0|                MirType::Pointer { pointee } => {
 1339|      0|                    let pointee_type = ctx.mir.get_type(*pointee);
 1340|      0|                    if let MirType::Record { layout, .. } = pointee_type {
 1341|      0|                        let offset = layout
 1342|      0|                            .field_offsets
 1343|      0|                            .get(*field_index)
 1344|      0|                            .copied()
 1345|      0|                            .ok_or_else(|| format!("Field index {} out of bounds", field_index))?;
 1346|      0|                        (offset, true)
 1347|       |                    } else {
 1348|      0|                        return Err("Base of StructField is not a struct type".to_string());
 1349|       |                    }
 1350|       |                }
 1351|      0|                _ => return Err("Base of StructField is not a struct type".to_string()),
 1352|       |            };
 1353|       |
 1354|     12|            let final_addr = if is_pointer {
 1355|       |                // If the base is a pointer, we need to load the address it points to first
 1356|      0|                ctx.builder.ins().load(types::I64, MemFlags::new(), base_addr, 0)
 1357|       |            } else {
 1358|     12|                base_addr
 1359|       |            };
 1360|       |
 1361|     12|            let offset_val = ctx.builder.ins().iconst(types::I64, field_offset as i64);
 1362|     12|            Ok(ctx.builder.ins().iadd(final_addr, offset_val))
 1363|       |        }
 1364|     14|        Place::ArrayIndex(base_place, index_operand) => {
 1365|       |            // Get the base address of the array/pointer
 1366|     14|            let base_addr = resolve_place_to_addr(base_place, ctx)?;
                                                                                ^0
 1367|       |
 1368|       |            // Resolve the index operand to a value
 1369|     14|            let index_val = resolve_operand(index_operand, ctx, types::I64)?;
                                                                                         ^0
 1370|       |
 1371|       |            // Determine the element size using pre-computed layout information
 1372|     14|            let base_place_type_id = get_place_type_id(base_place, ctx.mir);
 1373|     14|            let base_type = ctx.mir.get_type(base_place_type_id);
 1374|       |
 1375|       |            // If the base is a pointer, we must load the pointer value from the base address
 1376|       |            // before adding the element offset. For arrays, the base address is already
 1377|       |            // the address of the first element.
 1378|     14|            let (element_size, final_base_addr) = match base_type {
 1379|     14|                MirType::Array { layout, .. } => (layout.stride as u32, base_addr),
 1380|      0|                MirType::Pointer { pointee } => {
 1381|      0|                    let pointee_type = ctx.mir.get_type(*pointee);

 1383|      0|                    let loaded_ptr = ctx.builder.ins().load(types::I64, MemFlags::new(), base_addr, 0);
 1384|      0|                    (size, loaded_ptr)
 1385|       |                }
 1386|      0|                _ => return Err("Base of ArrayIndex is not an array or pointer".to_string()),

    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module provides functionality to dump MIR in a human-readable format
    4|       |//! following the C11 compiler's specific conventions:
    5|       |//! - Local variables: %0, %1, %tmp3

    7|       |//! - Basic blocks: bb0, bb1
    8|       |//! - Constants: const 42, const null

    1|       |//! MIR Validation Pass
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! This module implements a validation pass that ensures MIR is well-formed
    4|       |//! and ready for code generation. The validation pass checks:
    5|       |//! - All locals have types
    6|       |//! - All blocks end with a Terminator
    7|       |//! - No illegal operations remain
    8|       |//! - MIR is Cranelift-safe

  104|       |/// MIR Validation Pass
  105|       |///
  106|       |/// This pass validates that MIR is well-formed and ready for code generation.
  107|       |/// It performs comprehensive checks but does not modify the MIR.

  498|       |/// Parse abstract declarator (for type names without identifiers)
  499|     41|pub(crate) fn parse_abstract_declarator(parser: &mut Parser) -> Result<ParsedDeclarator, ParseError> {
  500|     41|    debug!(
  501|      0|        "parse_abstract_declarator: starting at position {}, token {:?}",
  502|       |        parser.current_idx,
  503|      0|        parser.current_token_kind()
  504|       |    );
  505|       |
  506|       |    // Check for __attribute__ at the beginning (GCC extension)

  509|       |    {

  513|       |    // Parse leading pointers and their qualifiers

  518|     41|        match token.kind {

  521|      0|                    parser.advance(); // consume type name
  522|       |                    // Check if next is identifier for named abstract declarator
  523|      0|                    if let Some(next_token) = parser.try_current_token() {
  524|      0|                        if let TokenKind::Identifier(name) = next_token.kind {
  525|      0|                            parser.advance(); // consume identifier
  526|      0|                            ParsedDeclarator::Identifier(name, TypeQualifiers::empty())
  527|       |                        } else {
  528|      0|                            ParsedDeclarator::Abstract
  529|       |                        }
  530|       |                    } else {
  531|      0|                        ParsedDeclarator::Abstract
  532|       |                    }
  533|       |                } else {
  534|      5|                    parser.advance(); // consume invalid identifier
  535|      5|                    ParsedDeclarator::Abstract
  536|       |                }
  537|       |            }
  538|       |            TokenKind::Int => {
  539|      0|                parser.advance(); // consume int
  540|       |                // Check if next is identifier
  541|      0|                if let Some(next_token) = parser.try_current_token() {
  542|      0|                    if let TokenKind::Identifier(name) = next_token.kind {
  543|      0|                        parser.advance(); // consume identifier
  544|      0|                        ParsedDeclarator::Identifier(name, TypeQualifiers::empty())
  545|       |                    } else {
  546|      0|                        ParsedDeclarator::Abstract
  547|       |                    }
  548|       |                } else {
  549|      0|                    ParsedDeclarator::Abstract
  550|       |                }

  553|     18|                debug!("parse_abstract_declarator: found LeftParen");
                                     ^0

  556|       |                // If so, we treat it as a function declarator applied to an empty abstract declarator,
  557|       |                // instead of consuming the paren as a parenthesized declarator.
  558|       |                // We also check for `()` which is an empty parameter list.

  560|     18|                    if next_token.kind == TokenKind::Attribute {

  562|       |                        // If Attribute is followed by *, it's likely a parenthesized declarator.
  563|      2|                        if let Some(after_attr) = peek_past_attribute(parser, 0) {
  564|      2|                            after_attr.kind != TokenKind::Star
  565|       |                        } else {

  567|      0|                            true
  568|       |                        }
  569|       |                    } else {
  570|     16|                        parser.is_type_name_start_token(next_token) || next_token.kind == TokenKind::RightParen

  571|       |                    }
  572|       |                } else {

  574|       |                };

  576|     18|                if is_param_list_start {
  577|       |                    // It's a suffix, e.g. `(int)` in `int (int)`.
  578|       |                    // We return Abstract so the trailing declarator parser picks it up as a function declarator.
  579|      6|                    ParsedDeclarator::Abstract
  580|       |                } else {

  582|     12|                    if parser.accept(TokenKind::RightParen).is_some() {

  585|       |                        // Although if peek failed, we probably hit EOF soon.
  586|      0|                        ParsedDeclarator::Function {
  587|      0|                            inner: Box::new(ParsedDeclarator::Abstract),
  588|      0|                            params: ThinVec::new(),
  589|      0|                            is_variadic: false,
  590|      0|                        }
  591|       |                    } else {
  592|     12|                        let start_idx = parser.current_idx;
  593|     12|                        let inner_declarator = parse_abstract_declarator(parser)?;

  413|      3|    parser: &mut Parser,
  414|      3|    compound_stmt_node_ref: ParsedNodeRef,
  415|      3|) -> ParsedNodeRef {

   85|      1|                            BinaryOp::BitOr => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val | r_val, is_unsigned)),

   87|      1|                            BinaryOp::BitAnd => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val & r_val, is_unsigned)),
   88|     23|                            BinaryOp::Equal => Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val == r_val)),
   89|      1|                            BinaryOp::NotEqual => Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val != r_val)),
   90|       |                            BinaryOp::Less => {
   91|      2|                                if is_unsigned {
   92|      1|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val < r_val))
   93|       |                                } else {
   94|      1|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool((l_val as i64) < (r_val as i64)))
   95|       |                                }
   96|       |                            }
   97|       |                            BinaryOp::LessEqual => {
   98|      1|                                if is_unsigned {
   99|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val <= r_val))
  100|       |                                } else {
  101|      1|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool((l_val as i64) <= (r_val as i64)))
  102|       |                                }
  103|       |                            }
  104|       |                            BinaryOp::Greater => {
  105|      3|                                if is_unsigned {
  106|      1|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val > r_val))
  107|       |                                } else {
  108|      2|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool((l_val as i64) > (r_val as i64)))
  109|       |                                }
  110|       |                            }
  111|       |                            BinaryOp::GreaterEqual => {
  112|      2|                                if is_unsigned {
  113|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(l_val >= r_val))
  114|       |                                } else {
  115|      2|                                    Ok(ExprValue::from_bool((l_val as i64) >= (r_val as i64)))
  116|       |                                }
  117|       |                            }
  118|       |                            BinaryOp::LShift => {
  119|       |                                // Shift count is not subject to usual arithmetic conversions for type
  120|       |                                // But the result type is that of the promoted LHS.
  121|       |                                // We'll just use the promoted LHS type (integer promotion, but here we are already 64-bit).
  122|       |                                // C11: "The result has the type of the left operand."
  123|       |                                // So we preserve l.is_unsigned.
  124|      1|                                let shift_amount = r_val as u32;
  125|       |                                // Handle shift >= 64 behavior (UB in C, wrap in Rust)
  126|      1|                                if shift_amount >= 64 {
  127|       |                                    // UB, but zeroing is a common safe behavior or wrapping.
  128|       |                                    // Rust panics in debug on overflow, wrapping_shl masks.
  129|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_shl(shift_amount), l.is_unsigned))
  130|       |                                } else {
  131|      1|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val << shift_amount, l.is_unsigned))
  132|       |                                }
  133|       |                            }
  134|       |                            BinaryOp::RShift => {
  135|      1|                                let shift_amount = r_val as u32;
  136|      1|                                if shift_amount >= 64 {
  137|       |                                    // UB
  138|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_shr(shift_amount), l.is_unsigned))
  139|      1|                                } else if l.is_unsigned {
  140|       |                                    // Logical shift
  141|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val >> shift_amount, true))
  142|       |                                } else {
  143|       |                                    // Arithmetic shift
  144|      1|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(((l_val as i64) >> shift_amount) as u64, false))
  145|       |                                }
  146|       |                            }
  147|      4|                            BinaryOp::Add => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_add(r_val), is_unsigned)),
  148|      1|                            BinaryOp::Sub => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_sub(r_val), is_unsigned)),
  149|      4|                            BinaryOp::Mul => Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val.wrapping_mul(r_val), is_unsigned)),
  150|       |                            BinaryOp::Div => {
  151|      2|                                if r_val == 0 {
  152|      1|                                    Err(PPError::InvalidConditionalExpression)
  153|      1|                                } else if is_unsigned {
  154|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val / r_val, true))
  155|       |                                } else {
  156|       |                                    // Signed division
  157|       |                                    // Check for overflow: MIN / -1
  158|      1|                                    let l_signed = l_val as i64;
  159|      1|                                    let r_signed = r_val as i64;
  160|      1|                                    if l_signed == i64::MIN && r_signed == -1 {
                                                                             ^0
  161|      0|                                        Ok(ExprValue::new(l_signed as u64, false)) // or overflow behavior
  162|       |                                    } else {
  163|      1|                                        Ok(ExprValue::new((l_signed / r_signed) as u64, false))
  164|       |                                    }
  165|       |                                }
  166|       |                            }
  167|       |                            BinaryOp::Mod => {
  168|      1|                                if r_val == 0 {
  169|      0|                                    Err(PPError::InvalidConditionalExpression)
  170|      1|                                } else if is_unsigned {
  171|      0|                                    Ok(ExprValue::new(l_val % r_val, true))
  172|       |                                } else {
  173|      1|                                    let l_signed = l_val as i64;
  174|      1|                                    let r_signed = r_val as i64;
  175|      1|                                    if l_signed == i64::MIN && r_signed == -1 {
                                                                             ^0
  176|      0|                                        Ok(ExprValue::new(0, false))
  177|       |                                    } else {
  178|      1|                                        Ok(ExprValue::new((l_signed % r_signed) as u64, false))
  179|       |                                    }
  180|       |                                }
  181|       |                            }
  182|      0|                            _ => unreachable!(),
  183|       |                        }
  184|       |                    }
  185|       |                }
  186|       |            }
  187|      9|            PPExpr::Unary(op, operand) => {
  188|      9|                let o = operand.evaluate(pp)?;
                                                          ^0
  189|      9|                match op {
  190|      0|                    UnaryOp::Plus => Ok(o),
  191|       |                    UnaryOp::Minus => {
  192|       |                        // Unsigned negation is 2's complement (wrapping_neg)
  193|      4|                        Ok(ExprValue::new(o.value.wrapping_neg(), o.is_unsigned))
  194|       |                    }
  195|      1|                    UnaryOp::BitNot => Ok(ExprValue::new(!o.value, o.is_unsigned)),
  196|      4|                    UnaryOp::LogicNot => Ok(ExprValue::from_bool(!o.is_truthy())),
  197|      0|                    _ => unreachable!("Unsupported unary operator in preprocessor"),
  198|       |                }
  199|       |            }
  200|      0|            PPExpr::Conditional(cond, true_e, false_e) => {
  201|      0|                let c = cond.evaluate(pp)?;
  202|      0|                let t = true_e.evaluate(pp)?;
  203|      0|                let f = false_e.evaluate(pp)?;
  204|       |
  205|      0|                if c.is_truthy() {
  206|       |                    // Result type depends on both operands usual arithmetic conversions
  207|       |                    // But we only return the evaluated one.
  208|       |                    // However, C11 says "the other operand is evaluated ... The result has the type..."
  209|       |                    // In an interpreter, we just return the value.
  210|       |                    // But if we wanted to be pedantic about type of the expression (e.g. for `sizeof`),
  211|       |                    // we would need to merge types.
  212|       |                    // But here we just return the value.
  213|       |                    // Wait, if I have `1 ? -1 : 0U`. Result should be unsigned.
  214|       |                    // `-1` converted to unsigned is MAX.
  215|       |                    // If we return `-1` as signed, and later compare it...
  216|       |                    // "The second and third operands are converted ... to the common type."
  217|      0|                    let is_unsigned = t.is_unsigned || f.is_unsigned;
  218|      0|                    if is_unsigned {
  219|      0|                        Ok(ExprValue::new(t.value, true))
  220|       |                    } else {
  221|      0|                        Ok(t)
  222|       |                    }
  223|       |                } else {
  224|      0|                    let is_unsigned = t.is_unsigned || f.is_unsigned;
  225|      0|                    if is_unsigned {
  226|      0|                        Ok(ExprValue::new(f.value, true))
  227|       |                    } else {
  228|      0|                        Ok(f)
  229|       |                    }
  230|       |                }
  231|       |            }
  232|       |        }
  233|    188|    }

  340|       |    ///  Bolt: Consolidated operator lexing.

  345|  6.31k|    fn lex_operator(&mut self, start_pos: u32, ch: u8, flags: PPTokenFlags) -> PPToken {

  750|       |    /// Consumes characters based on a predicate, building a string.
  751|       |    ///
  752|       |    /// The predicate receives the current state and the character.
  753|       |    /// It should return `true` to consume the character, or `false` to stop.
  754|       |    /// The closure can modify state (e.g., tracking scientific notation 'e').
  755|  1.13k|    fn consume_while<F, S>(&mut self, mut state: S, first_ch: u8, mut pred: F) -> String
  756|  1.13k|    where
  757|  1.13k|        F: FnMut(&mut S, u8) -> bool,
  758|       |    {

                                     ^2.05k

  762|    963|                chars.push(self.next_char().unwrap());
  763|    963|            } else {
  764|  1.08k|                break;
  765|       |            }
  766|       |        }
  767|       |        // Safety: We assume the caller only consumes valid UTF-8 characters (identifiers/numbers)
  768|       |        // or we handle validation later. For identifiers/numbers constructed from ascii, this is safe.
  769|       |        // Actually, identifiers can contain unicode in some extensions, but here we assume standard handling.
  770|       |        // PPLexer usually deals with bytes, but text tokens are generally UTF-8 compatible.
  771|  1.13k|        String::from_utf8(chars).unwrap()
  772|  1.13k|    }

  798|       |    /// Try to parse a UCN.
  799|       |    /// Assumes the leading backslash has already been consumed.
  800|       |    /// Returns:
  801|       |    /// - None: Not a UCN (didn't consume anything).

  803|       |    /// - Some(Err(raw_string)): Invalid UCN (consumed raw_string).
  804|     53|    fn lex_ucn(&mut self, allow_basic_charset: bool) -> Option<Result<(char, String), String>> {

  816|      7|        for _ in 0..digits_needed {

  819|     28|                    self.next_char();

  821|     28|                } else {
  822|      0|                    break;
  823|       |                }
  824|       |            } else {
  825|      0|                break;

  831|       |

  833|      0|            return Some(Err(raw_string));
  834|      7|        }
  835|       |

  837|       |

  841|      0|            return Some(Err(raw_string));
  842|      7|        }

  683|       |    /// Convert a list of tokens to a path string
  684|     19|    fn tokens_to_path_string(&self, tokens: &[PPToken]) -> String {
  685|       |        // Bolt : Use a two-pass approach to build the path string efficiently.
  686|       |        // This avoids multiple reallocations from push_str in a loop, a known
  687|       |        // performance anti-pattern in this codebase.
  688|       |        // 1. Calculate the total length of the path.
  689|     63|        let total_len = tokens.iter().map(|part| part.length as usize).sum();
                          ^19         ^19    ^19    ^19                              ^19
  690|       |
  691|       |        // 2. Allocate the string with the exact capacity.
  692|     19|        let mut path = String::with_capacity(total_len);
  693|       |
  694|       |        // 3. Populate the string.
  695|     63|        for part in tokens.iter() {
                                  ^19    ^19
  696|     63|            let buffer = self.source_manager.get_buffer(part.location.source_id());
  697|     63|            let start = part.location.offset() as usize;
  698|     63|            let end = start + part.length as usize;
  699|     63|            if end <= buffer.len() {
  700|     63|                let text = unsafe { std::str::from_utf8_unchecked(&buffer[start..end]) };
  701|     63|                path.push_str(text);
  702|     63|            }
                          ^0
  703|       |        }
  704|     19|        path
  705|     19|    }

 1997|      7|    fn parse_pragma_message_content(&mut self) -> Result<String, PPError> {
 1998|       |        // Expect '('

 2037|      8|                    message.push_str(&self.destringize(s));
 2038|      8|                } else {
 2039|      0|                    return Err(PPError::InvalidDirective);

 2042|      0|                return Err(PPError::InvalidDirective);

 2123|      1|    fn consume_rest_of_line_as_string(&mut self) -> String {
 2124|       |        // Optimization: Avoid multiple small allocations by calculating final string size first.
 2125|       |        // This follows the two-pass approach:
 2126|       |        // 1. Collect tokens for the line.
 2127|       |        // 2. Calculate the total length required for the string.
 2128|       |        // 3. Allocate a single string with the required capacity.
 2129|       |        // 4. Populate the string in a second pass over the tokens.
 2130|      1|        let mut tokens = Vec::new();
 2131|      2|        while let Some(token) = self.lex_token() {
 2132|      2|            if token.kind == PPTokenKind::Eod {
 2133|      1|                break;
 2134|      1|            }
 2135|      1|            tokens.push(token);
 2136|       |        }
 2137|       |
 2138|      1|        if tokens.is_empty() {
 2139|      0|            return String::new();
 2140|      1|        }
 2141|       |
 2142|       |        // Calculate total length
 2143|      1|        let mut total_len = 0;
 2144|      1|        for (i, token) in tokens.iter().enumerate() {
 2145|      1|            total_len += token.length as usize;
 2146|      1|            if i > 0 {
 2147|      0|                total_len += 1; // For the space separator
 2148|      1|            }
 2149|       |        }
 2150|       |
 2151|       |        // Allocate and build the string
 2152|      1|        let mut result = String::with_capacity(total_len);
 2153|      1|        for (i, token) in tokens.iter().enumerate() {
 2154|      1|            if i > 0 {
 2155|      0|                result.push(' ');
 2156|      1|            }
 2157|      1|            let buffer = self.source_manager.get_buffer(token.location.source_id());
 2158|      1|            let start = token.location.offset() as usize;
 2159|      1|            let end = start + token.length as usize;
 2160|      1|            if end <= buffer.len() {
 2161|      1|                // This is safe because the lexer guarantees tokens are valid UTF-8.
 2162|      1|                let text = unsafe { std::str::from_utf8_unchecked(&buffer[start..end]) };
 2163|      1|                result.push_str(text);
 2164|      1|            }
                          ^0
 2165|       |        }
 2166|       |
 2167|      1|        result
 2168|      1|    }

 3302|       |

 3308|       |
 3309|       |        // Test case 5: Mixed and complex cases
 3310|      1|        assert_eq!(pp.destringize("\"a\\\\\\\"b\\tc\\123d\\x41g\""), "a\\\"b\tcSdAg");
 3311|       |
 3312|       |        // Test case 6: Empty string
 3313|      1|        assert_eq!(pp.destringize("\"\""), "");
 3314|      1|    }

  118|       |    /// Recursively visit type to find any expressions (e.g. VLA sizes) and resolve them.
  119|    758|    fn visit_type_expressions(&mut self, qt: QualType) {
  120|    758|        let ty = qt.ty();
  121|       |        //  Bolt: Optimized duplicate check.
  122|       |        // `HashSet::insert` returns `false` if the value was already present.
  123|       |        // This is faster than calling `contains` and then `insert`, as it
  124|       |        // performs a single lookup instead of two.
  125|    758|        if !self.checked_types.insert(ty) {
  126|    327|            return;

  129|       |        // To avoid infinite recursion on recursive types (e.g. struct A { struct A *next; }),
  130|       |        // we rely on checked_types.
  131|       |        // Note: We need to clone the kind to avoid borrowing self.registry while calling self methods
  132|    431|        let kind = self.registry.get(ty).kind.clone();

  134|    431|        match kind {

                                                             ^2

  140|       |            }

  142|     71|                self.visit_type_expressions(pointee);
  143|     71|            }
  144|       |            TypeKind::Function {

  147|       |                ..

  154|      0|            TypeKind::Complex { base_type } => {
  155|      0|                self.visit_type_expressions(QualType::unqualified(base_type));
  156|      0|            }
  157|       |            // For Records and Enums, we don't need to traverse members because
  158|       |            // they cannot contain VLAs (C11 6.7.2.1).
  159|       |            // Even if they did, the members would be visited during their declaration processing.

 1891|  3.06k|    fn visit_node(&mut self, node_ref: NodeRef) -> Option<QualType> {
 1892|  3.06k|        let node_kind = self.ast.get_kind(node_ref);
 1893|  3.06k|        let result_type = match node_kind {
 1894|       |            // Declarations
 1895|       |            NodeKind::TranslationUnit(_)
 1896|       |            | NodeKind::Function(_)
 1897|       |            | NodeKind::VarDecl(_)
 1898|       |            | NodeKind::RecordDecl(_)
 1899|       |            | NodeKind::FieldDecl(_)
 1900|       |            | NodeKind::EnumDecl(_)
 1901|       |            | NodeKind::EnumMember(_)
 1902|       |            | NodeKind::TypedefDecl(_)
 1903|       |            | NodeKind::EnumConstant(..)
 1904|       |            | NodeKind::Param(_)
 1905|    917|            | NodeKind::FunctionDecl(_) => self.visit_declaration_node(node_ref, node_kind),

  726|    170|    pub(crate) fn emit_assignment(&mut self, place: Place, operand: Operand) {
  727|    170|        if self.mir_builder.current_block_has_terminator() {
  728|      0|            return;
  729|    170|        }
  730|       |

  732|    170|        if let Operand::Copy(box_place) = &operand

  733|     56|            && **box_place == place
  734|       |        {
  735|     11|            return;

  737|       |
  738|    159|        let rvalue = Rvalue::Use(operand);
  739|    159|        let stmt = MirStmt::Assign(place, rvalue);
  740|    159|        self.mir_builder.add_statement(stmt);
  741|    170|    }

  382|      0|                }

  385|      0|            } else if lhs_mir.is_int() && rhs_mir.is_pointer() {

  392|     54|    pub(crate) fn lower_binary_op_expr(
  393|     54|        &mut self,
  394|     54|        op: &BinaryOp,
  395|     54|        left_ref: NodeRef,
  396|     54|        right_ref: NodeRef,
  397|     54|        mir_ty: TypeId,
  398|     54|    ) -> Operand {

  402|       |            op
  403|       |        );

  406|     50|        }

  409|     50|        let rhs = self.lower_expression(right_ref, true);
  410|       |
  411|       |        // Handle pointer arithmetic
  412|       |

  415|     50|        }
  416|       |

  418|     50|        let lhs_converted = self.apply_conversions(lhs, left_ref, mir_ty);
  419|     50|        let rhs_converted = self.apply_conversions(rhs, right_ref, mir_ty);
  420|       |

  422|     50|        let lhs_mir_ty = self.get_operand_type(&lhs_converted);

  424|       |

  427|       |

  429|     50|        let rhs_final = self.ensure_explicit_cast(rhs_converted, right_ref);
  430|       |

  432|     50|        let lhs_mir = self.mir_builder.get_type(lhs_mir_ty);
  433|       |

  453|       |        }

  456|      4|    pub(crate) fn emit_bool_normalization(
  457|      4|        &mut self,
  458|      4|        value_op: Operand,
  459|      4|        result_place: Place,
  460|      4|        merge_block: crate::mir::MirBlockId,
  461|      4|    ) {

  464|       |
  465|      4|        self.mir_builder
  466|      4|            .set_terminator(Terminator::If(value_op, true_block, false_block));
  467|       |
  468|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(true_block);
  469|      4|        let one_op = self.create_int_operand(1);
  470|      4|        self.mir_builder
  471|      4|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(result_place.clone(), Rvalue::Use(one_op)));
  472|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(merge_block));
  473|       |
  474|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(false_block);
  475|      4|        let zero_op = self.create_int_operand(0);
  476|      4|        self.mir_builder
  477|      4|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(result_place.clone(), Rvalue::Use(zero_op)));
  478|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(merge_block));
  479|      4|    }
  480|       |
  481|      4|    pub(crate) fn lower_logical_op(
  482|      4|        &mut self,
  483|      4|        op: &BinaryOp,
  484|      4|        left_ref: NodeRef,
  485|      4|        right_ref: NodeRef,
  486|      4|        mir_ty: TypeId,
  487|      4|    ) -> Operand {
  488|       |        // Short-circuiting logic for && and ||
  489|      4|        let (_res_local, res_place) = self.create_temp_local(mir_ty);
  490|       |
  491|      4|        let eval_rhs_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  492|      4|        let merge_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  493|      4|        let short_circuit_block = self.mir_builder.create_block();
  494|       |
  495|       |        // 1. Evaluate LHS
  496|      4|        let lhs_op = self.lower_condition(left_ref);
  497|       |
  498|       |        // Pre-create constants to avoid double borrow
  499|      4|        let zero_op = self.create_int_operand(0);
  500|      4|        let one_op = self.create_int_operand(1);
  501|       |
  502|      4|        let (short_circuit_val, true_target, false_target) = match op {
  503|      0|            BinaryOp::LogicAnd => (zero_op.clone(), eval_rhs_block, short_circuit_block),
  504|      4|            BinaryOp::LogicOr => (one_op.clone(), short_circuit_block, eval_rhs_block),
  505|      0|            _ => unreachable!(),
  506|       |        };
  507|       |
  508|       |        // if lhs { goto true_target } else { goto false_target }
  509|      4|        self.mir_builder
  510|      4|            .set_terminator(Terminator::If(lhs_op, true_target, false_target));
  511|       |
  512|       |        // Short circuit case
  513|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(short_circuit_block);
  514|      4|        self.mir_builder
  515|      4|            .add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(res_place.clone(), Rvalue::Use(short_circuit_val)));
  516|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_terminator(Terminator::Goto(merge_block));
  517|       |
  518|       |        // 2. Evaluate RHS
  519|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(eval_rhs_block);
  520|      4|        let rhs_val = self.lower_condition(right_ref);
  521|       |
  522|      4|        self.emit_bool_normalization(rhs_val, res_place.clone(), merge_block);
  523|       |
  524|       |        // Merge
  525|      4|        self.mir_builder.set_current_block(merge_block);
  526|      4|        self.current_block = Some(merge_block);
  527|       |
  528|      4|        Operand::Copy(Box::new(res_place))
  529|      4|    }

  531|     60|    pub(crate) fn lower_pointer_arithmetic(
  532|     60|        &mut self,
  533|     60|        op: &BinaryOp,
  534|     60|        lhs: Operand,
  535|     60|        rhs: Operand,

  549|      0|                    let lhs_mir_ty = self.lower_qual_type(lhs_type);

  554|       |                }

  560|      1|                    } else if rhs_type.is_integer() {

  566|       |                    }

  570|       |            }

  572|       |        }

  575|     78|    pub(crate) fn lower_assignment_expr(
  576|     78|        &mut self,
  577|     78|        node_ref: NodeRef,
  578|     78|        op: &BinaryOp,
  579|     78|        left_ref: NodeRef,
  580|     78|        right_ref: NodeRef,
  581|     78|        mir_ty: TypeId,
  582|     78|    ) -> Operand {

  584|     78|            op.is_assignment(),
  585|      0|            "lower_assignment_expr called with non-assignment operator: {:?}",
  586|       |            op
  587|       |        );
  588|     78|        let lhs_op = self.lower_expression(left_ref, true);
  589|       |
  590|       |        // Ensure the LHS is a place. If not, this is a semantic error.
  591|     78|        if self.ast.get_value_category(left_ref) != Some(ValueCategory::LValue) {
  592|      0|            panic!("LHS of assignment must be an lvalue");
  593|     78|        }
  594|       |
  595|     78|        let place = if let Operand::Copy(place) = lhs_op {
  596|     78|            *place
  597|       |        } else {
  598|      0|            panic!("LHS of assignment lowered to non-place operand despite being LValue");
  599|       |        };

  602|       |

                                                  ^10

  605|     10|                node_ref,
  606|     10|                compound_op,
  607|     10|                place.clone(),
  608|     10|                rhs_op,
  609|     10|                left_ref,
  610|     10|                right_ref,
  611|     10|                mir_ty,
  612|       |            )
  613|       |        } else {
  614|       |            // Simple assignment, just use the RHS
  615|     68|            self.apply_conversions(rhs_op, right_ref, mir_ty)
  616|       |        };
  617|       |
  618|     78|        self.emit_assignment(place, final_rhs.clone());
  619|     78|        final_rhs // C assignment expressions evaluate to the assigned value
  620|     78|    }

  622|     10|    pub(crate) fn lower_compound_assignment(
  623|     10|        &mut self,
  624|     10|        node_ref: NodeRef,
  625|     10|        compound_op: BinaryOp,
  626|     10|        place: Place,
  627|     10|        rhs_op: Operand,
  628|     10|        left_ref: NodeRef,
  629|     10|        right_ref: NodeRef,
  630|     10|        mir_ty: TypeId,
  631|     10|    ) -> Operand {
  632|       |        // This is a compound assignment, e.g., a += b
  633|       |        // Use the already-evaluated place to read the current value.
  634|     10|        let lhs_copy = Operand::Copy(Box::new(place));
  635|       |
  636|      2|        if let Some(rval) =
  637|     10|            self.lower_pointer_arithmetic(&compound_op, lhs_copy.clone(), rhs_op.clone(), left_ref, right_ref)
  638|       |        {
  639|      2|            self.emit_rvalue_to_operand(rval, mir_ty)
  640|       |        } else {
  641|      8|            let lhs_converted_for_op = self.apply_conversions(lhs_copy, left_ref, mir_ty);
  642|      8|            let rhs_converted_for_op = self.apply_conversions(rhs_op, right_ref, mir_ty);
  643|       |
  644|      8|            let lhs_ty_for_op = self.get_operand_type(&lhs_converted_for_op);
  645|      8|            let mir_type_info = self.mir_builder.get_type(lhs_ty_for_op);
  646|       |
  647|      8|            let rval = mir_ops::emit_binary_rvalue(
  648|      8|                &compound_op,
  649|      8|                lhs_converted_for_op,
  650|      8|                rhs_converted_for_op,
  651|      8|                mir_type_info.is_float(),
  652|       |            );
  653|      8|            let result_of_op = self.emit_rvalue_to_operand(rval, lhs_ty_for_op);
  654|      8|            self.apply_conversions(result_of_op, node_ref, mir_ty)
  655|       |        }
  656|     10|    }

  820|      9|    pub(crate) fn lower_inc_dec_common(
  821|      9|        &mut self,
  822|      9|        operand_ref: NodeRef,
  823|      9|        is_inc: bool,
  824|      9|        is_post: bool,
  825|      9|        need_value: bool,
  826|      9|    ) -> Operand {
  827|      9|        let operand = self.lower_expression(operand_ref, true);
  828|      9|        let operand_ty = self.ast.get_resolved_type(operand_ref).unwrap();
  829|      9|        let mir_ty = self.lower_qual_type(operand_ty);
  830|       |
  831|      9|        if self.ast.get_value_category(operand_ref) != Some(ValueCategory::LValue) {
  832|      0|            panic!("Inc/Dec operand must be an lvalue");
  833|      9|        }
  834|       |
  835|      9|        let place = if let Operand::Copy(place) = operand.clone() {
  836|      9|            place
  837|       |        } else {
  838|      0|            panic!("Inc/Dec operand is not a place");
  839|       |        };
  840|       |
  841|       |        // If it's post-inc/dec and we need the value, save the old value
  842|      9|        let old_value = if is_post && need_value {
                                                    ^7
  843|      4|            let rval = Rvalue::Use(operand.clone());
  844|      4|            let (_, temp_place) = self.create_temp_local_with_assignment(rval, mir_ty);
  845|      4|            Some(Operand::Copy(Box::new(temp_place)))
  846|       |        } else {
  847|      5|            None
  848|       |        };
  849|       |
  850|       |        // Determine MIR operation and Rvalue
  851|      9|        let rval = self.create_inc_dec_rvalue(operand.clone(), operand_ty, is_inc);
  852|       |
  853|       |        // Perform the assignment
  854|      9|        if is_post && !need_value {
                                    ^7
  855|      3|            // Optimization: assign directly to place if old value not needed
  856|      3|            self.mir_builder.add_statement(MirStmt::Assign(*place.clone(), rval));
  857|      3|        } else {
  858|       |            // If we needed old value (is_post), or if it is pre-inc (need new value),
  859|       |            // we compute to a temp first to ensure correctness and return the right value.
  860|      6|            let (_, new_place) = self.create_temp_local_with_assignment(rval, mir_ty);
  861|      6|            self.emit_assignment(*place.clone(), Operand::Copy(Box::new(new_place.clone())));
  862|       |
  863|      6|            if !is_post {
  864|       |                // Pre-inc: return the new value
  865|      2|                return Operand::Copy(Box::new(new_place));
  866|      4|            }
  867|       |        }
  868|       |
  869|      7|        if is_post {
  870|      7|            if need_value {
  871|      4|                old_value.unwrap()
  872|       |            } else {
  873|      3|                self.create_int_operand(0)
  874|       |            }
  875|       |        } else {
  876|       |            // Pre-inc: we already returned inside the block above.
  877|       |            // RE-FETCH from place as a fallback (should not be reached)
  878|      0|            Operand::Copy(place)
  879|       |        }
  880|      9|    }

  882|      9|    pub(crate) fn create_inc_dec_rvalue(&mut self, operand: Operand, operand_ty: QualType, is_inc: bool) -> Rvalue {
  883|      9|        let one_const = self.create_int_operand(1);
  884|      9|        let minus_one_const = self.create_int_operand(-1);
  885|       |
  886|      9|        if operand_ty.is_pointer() {
  887|      0|            if is_inc {
  888|      0|                Rvalue::PtrAdd(operand, one_const)
  889|       |            } else {
  890|      0|                Rvalue::PtrSub(operand, one_const)
  891|       |            }
  892|       |        } else {
  893|       |            // For Integers: Add(delta) (Note: we use Add with negative delta for decrement
  894|       |            // to support proper wrapping arithmetic and fix previous bugs)
  895|      9|            let rhs = if is_inc { one_const } else { minus_one_const };
                                                ^4                 ^5
  896|      9|            Rvalue::BinaryIntOp(BinaryIntOp::Add, operand, rhs)
  897|       |        }
  898|      9|    }

  938|     10|    pub(crate) fn lower_atomic_op(

  940|     10|        op: AtomicOp,
  941|     10|        args_start: NodeRef,

  494|       |    /// This implements C11 6.9.2 for handling tentative definitions, extern declarations, and actual definitions.

    1|       |//! Type Registry
    2|       |//!
    3|       |//! Arena + canonicalization layer for semantic types.
    4|       |//! All TypeRef creation and mutation MUST go through this context.
    5|       |
    6|       |use std::borrow::Cow;
    7|       |
    8|       |use crate::source_manager::SourceSpan;
    9|       |use crate::{ast::NameId, diagnostic::SemanticError, semantic::QualType};
   10|       |use hashbrown::{HashMap, HashSet};
   11|       |use target_lexicon::{PointerWidth, Triple};
